alert.note: Alert for Lewis; Pierce (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 28 at 12:05PM PST until March 02 at 7:42AM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Seattle WA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Washington... Puyallup River Near Orting affecting Pierce County. Nisqually River Near National affecting Lewis and Pierce Counties. Cowlitz River At Randle affecting Lewis County. .A strong storm is coming in to western Washington with multiple factors that will produce high runoff and flooding. Heavy, prolonged rainfall will be coupled with some snow snow melt in low to mid elevations of the mountains from rising snow levels and strong warm and moist winds. This will drive some rivers above minor to major flooding. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO WEDNESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Nisqually River Near National. * WHEN...From this evening to Wednesday morning. * IMPACTS...At 10000.0 cfs, the Nisqually River will flood along the upper reaches of the river from Mt Rainier National Park downstream to Alder Lake. Swift waters will flood roads...pasture lands...and farms. Erosion may damage the river banks. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:00 AM PST Monday the flow was 2580.0 cfs. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this evening to a crest of 13620 cfs late tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow evening. - Flood flow is 8000.0 cfs. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 13400.0 cfs on 01/07/2009. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this evening at 800 PM PST.
